Pit_Observation.pitNotes: exiting weather system

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent activity on different slopes; Instability rapidly rising; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: First profile of season, Deckers, shady treeline.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in open area below treeline.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Instability rapidly rising; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Fresh powder with no base on most slopes... thin faceted layer on the ground limited to north facing terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind effect from Nov. 23-26 was widespread. Two inches of new snow from Nov. 26/27 has camouflaged most of this wind drifting. Some drifts are sensitive, and we experienced some localized collapsing and shooting cracks.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Just getting a feel for early season conditions and working the bugs out of systems/gear. This slope was not steep enough to avalanche but was a similar aspect and elevation to nearby avalanche terrain.
Snow depth ranged from 1-3 feet depending on wind loads. the thinner spots were all facets.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Persistent moderate to strong southerly winds, snow surface becoming heat effected on solar aspects to upper elevation where protected from the wind. No sign of instability, coverage remains shallow and variable at upper elev, primary concern going into this series of storms is weakened surface snow, finding 0.5mm FCsf and 3-5mm SH on upper N asp, not finding old basal snow to be a widespread issue.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Recently wind loaded snow from the past 48 hours is the primary avalanche concern. Also notable are the facets around a stout crust in the middle of the pack around 50 cm. The pack is a bit denser than usual and generally stable for now.

Facets underneath the most recent storm snow appear to be getting larger and weaker. Near surface facets are beginning to develop within the recent storm snow. So far, there is not much of a slab on top of the weak layer.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

User.name: Andy Anderson
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: After the first ectp on the ice/ faceted interface on a 17 degree slope we dug two more ect s within 50m area on approximately North facing aspect - one on an 18 degree slope with propagation upon block seperation, the other on a 10 degree slope with ectn 11 on the same layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Poor pit location
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I dug this pit to see snow depth and metamorphosis, not immediate stability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on spine in open, complex, near treeline terrain.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: New snow amounts up to 15cm in this area. Most of this snow was on top of previously bare ground with the exception of north aspects above 9000' where very limited snow existed.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Early season. All 12 cm of snow were isothermal yet still remained structure. Likely Thursday's snow is damp up to 10,000' or higher and may not be as much of a weakness as previously imagined. Early season facets damp yet still primary layer of concern at this point until/unless "locked up" by cold snap.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in near treeline terrain.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The slope was wind loaded, but stable.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: A fair bit of collapsing observed, and 2 natural avalanches on a similar aspect about 1 mile away.
Snow cover on north aspects above 9200' in this area. Warmer temperatures today as the next storm approaches our forecast area. No surface hoar observed in this area.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Warmer air temperatures as the next storm approaches our region. No surface hoar observed in this area.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Mostly continuous snow above 8400' on northerly aspects. Surface hoar observed between 8200-8800' and up to 7-8mm in size.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: All snowpit work/data collection performed by Steve Reynaud - Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center. Pit dug in near treeline terrain. Numerous boulders on slope, making PST difficult to perform at 7 cm height.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: warm and wet. minor snowballing in top layer when pushed on.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in near treeline terrain. Strong temp gradients observed on top and bottom of basal ice. Snow cover 10 cm or less below 8,800'.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Thin fog. HS in this area at this elevation is composed entirely of recent storm snow from the Oct 30-Nov 1 storms. Tsurf and T10 temps not taken using dial stem due to current best understanding of methods.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug at treeline. Spot probing in nearby areas revealed HS up to 70cm. Tsurf and T10 temps not taken via dial stem due to current best method knowledge.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Hasty Pit. Lots of body. We exhibited poor decision-making by leaving our skis in the car!

Snowpack was isothermal below the crust. The recent snow down to the crust contained 1.75 inches (44.5 mm) of water. The old snow, which included the crust and isothermal snow to the ground, contained 2.05 inches (52 mm) of water.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: A few good turns here on a day when snow pack otherwise too thin: low angle supportive crust

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heavy wind loading past two days gusting up to 38mph, scouring lower and adjacent aspects and depositing snow in pit location.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in area representative to avalanche release that occurred on 3/19/1985. This avalanche resulted from a point release near adjacent rock bands. no shears or failure were noted above crust. No free water observed above crust. Hand Hardness tests were not standard practice at this time.
